title: Telephone Surveys and Types of Bias
question_text:
Janice received a telephone call from a research organization asking if she would be willing to answer a few questions about how often she buys certain types of groceries. Janice told the researcher that she was not interested in participating.
Nevertheless, two days later she received another phone call from the same organization asking if she would participate in their survey about buying certain types of groceries. Once again, Janice refused. When the same organization called her for a third time, Janice became irate. She told the researcher "No matter how many times you call me, I will not participate in your survey! Please do not call this number again!"
Which of the following best describes the type of bias Janice (and others like her) may have introduced into the research organization's survey results?

choices.text: Undercoverage bias may be present since information about how often Janice (and others like her) buy certain types of groceries will not be included in the survey results.

Voluntary response bias may be present since Janice did not voluntarily provide information about how often she buys certain types of groceries. The people who do voluntarily provide such information may differ from Janice in some way that would cause the survey results to be inaccurate.
Response bias may be present. Since Janice became irate when the organization called her for the third time, this interaction could affect the organization's survey results.

Non-response bias may be present. Since Janice (and probably many other people who were contacted by the research organization) would not cooperate with answering the researcher's questions, the results of the survey may not accurately represent the population of interest.
There is no chance that Janice's refusal to participate in the survey would introduce bias of any type.

solution:
Non-response bias occurs when an individual who was chosen to be part of a sample cannot be reached or refuses to participate.

If the individuals who fall into this category differ in some way with respect to the variable of interest from those who would choose to participate in the survey, the results may be inaccurate as they do not truly represent the population of interest. In this case, if people like Janice who will not participate in the survey buy more or less of the types of groceries discussed, then the results of the survey may be inaccurate.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect. Undercoverage occurs when a portion of the population of interest is somehow precluded from becoming part of the sample. In this situation, those without a telephone may be undercovered since the survey was conducted by telephone. However, Janice was not left out of the sample. She was chosen to be in the sample!

Choice 'B' is incorrect. Voluntary response bias refers to situations where individuals must actively volunteer themselves to become part of a sample. Janice did not volunteer herself to be part of the sample - she was already selected to be part of the sample. The fact that she did not participate does not make this an example of voluntary response bias.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. Response bias may occur in many ways. For example, if respondents do not answer the question truthfully, response bias would be present. Also, if questions are worded in a way that would lead someone to provide a certain type of answer, response bias would be present. However, Janice becoming irate with the telephone call does not qualify as response bias.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. There is a chance that Janice's refusal to participate did not create any bias in the survey results. However, there is also the chance that it did.
